summary: human coronavirus NL63 (HCoV-NL63) and 229E (HCoV-229E) belong to the alphacoronavirus genus, a member of the Coronaviridae family. coronaviruses are positive-strand RNA viruses with the largest genome of approximately 27–31 kb in size. a total of 2,060 consenting outpatients who presented with acute URTI symptoms were recruited at the Primary Care Clinic of University Malaya Medical Center in Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia, between March 2012 and February 2013. nasopharyngeal swabs were transferred to the laboratory in universal transport media and stored at 80°C. gene fragment sequencing of the S (S1 domain), complete N, and partial 1a (nsp3) genes was performed for HCoV-NL63 and HCoV-229E specimens. the PCR mixture (25 L) contained cDNA, PCR buffer (10 mM Tris-HCl [pH 8.3], 50 mM KCl, 3 mM MgCl, and 0.1% gelatin) the cycling conditions were as follows: initial denaturation at 95°C for 5 minutes followed by 40 cycles of 94°C for 1 minute, 54.5°C for 1 minute, 72°C for 1 minute, and a final extension at 72°C for 10 minutes. purified PCR products were sequenced using the ABI PRISM 3730XL DNA Analyzer. TTTGCTTAATTGCTTATGG 26 LPR 21,710–21,728 Reverse (nested): TTTGCTTAATTGCTTTTATGG 26 Nucleocapsid (N) NL63 and 229E N-F 26,102–26,127 (NL63) Forward (nested): ATAATAAACAKTCAACTGGAAT This study 229E E-NR 27,046–27,063 Reverse (nested): ATAATA maximum clade credibility (MCC) trees for the partial S (S1 domain), complete N, and partial 1a (nsp3) genes were reconstructed in BEAST (version 1.7) the trees were annotated using a relaxed molecular clock. inter-genotype pairwise nucleotide distances were estimated for the S gene using MEGA 5.1. such analysis was not implemented for the N and 1a genes due to their high genetic invariability across HCoV-NL63 and HCoV-229E genotypes. gene fragment sequencing of the S (S1 domain), complete N, and partial 1a (nsp3) genes was performed for HCoV-NL63 and HCoV-229E specimens. the presence of respiratory viruses in specimens was examined using the xTAG Respiratory Virus Panel FAST multiplex reverse transcriptase polymerase chain reaction assay. cDNA, PCR buffer (10 mM Tris-HCl [pH 8.3], 50 mM KCl, 3 mM MgCl, and 0.01% gelatin) cDNA, cDNA, PCR buffer (10 mM Tris-HCl [pH 8.3], 50 mM KCl, 3 mM MgCl, and 4 U/L BIO-X-ACT Short DNA polymerase. NL63 SP1F 20,390–20,412 Forward (nested): TGAGTTTGATTAAGAGTGGTAGG 25 SP1R 21,809–21,828 Reverse: CAAACTGCAAGTGCTCACAC 25 SP2R 21,797–21,816 Reverse (nested): GCTCACACTGCAACTTTTCA 25 229E LPS1 20,732–20,751 Forward: AATAATTGGTTCTAAC 26 f 5,778–5,798 Forward (semi-nested): CTTTTGATAACGGTCACTATG 27 P3E2-5Pf 5,789–5,810 Forward (semi-nested): GGTCATTATGATG 27 NL-1aR 6,593–6,616 Reverse: CTCATTACATAAAACATCRAACGG This study E-1aF 5,865–5,585 Forward (semi-nested): the best-fitting model was determined by the Bayes factor. the substitution rate of 3.3 104 substitutions/site/year for the S gene was estimated previously. nasopharyngeal swab specimens were screened for the presence of HCoV-NL63 and HCoV-229E. the results are consistent with the global average prevalence of human alphacoronavirus, which ranges between 1% and 10%. a peak in the number of HCoV-NL63 infections was recorded between June and October 2012. 68 adult outpatients infected with human alphacoronavirus in Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia, 2012–2013 Factor HCoV-NL63 (N = 45) HCoV-229E (N = 23) P value Gender 0.80 Male 25 (55.6%) 12 (52.2%) Female 20 (44.4%) 11 (47.8%) Age 0.45 40 13 (28.9%) 7 (30.4%) 40–60 10 (22.2%) 8 (34.8%) Symptoms 0.99 S phylogenetic analysis of HCoV-NL63 showed that 27 subjects (27/43, 62.8%) belonged to genotype B (supported by a posterior probability of 1.0 and bootstrap value of 100% at the internal nodes of the MCC and ML trees of the S gene) another 16 subjects (16/43, 37.2%) were found to be grouped under genotype C (supported by a posterior probability of 1.0 and bootstrap value of 100%) genetic distance between HCoV-NL63 genotypes A, B, and C was high (more than 5.0%), compared with that between genotypes A versus C, which was at 2.1%. this is consistent with the phylogenetic tree topology in which genotypes A and C were more closely related. group 3 2.5 1.2 - 0.3 group 4 3.5 2.6 1.5 - * Pairwise genetic distances are expressed in percentage (%) of nucleotide difference. at least one gene (S, N, and/or 1a) was successfully sequenced from 23 positively tested HCoV-229E specimens. the HCoV-229E groups 1–4 were indicated green = genotype 1, red = genotype 2, blue = genotype 3, and purple = genotype 4. the sampling site for each sequence was indicated by codes for the representation of countries. the mean evolutionary rates for the S gene of HCoV-NL63 and HCoV-229E were newly estimated based on the constant tree model. this is the first study that reported the divergence times of human alphacoronavirus genotypes. this is the first study that reported the divergence times of human alphacoronavirus genotypes. the most recently reported HCoV-229E strains from major parts of the world belong to group 4. a total of 2,060 nasopharyngeal swab specimens were screened for the presence of HCoV-NL63 and HCoV-229E in nasopharyngeal swabs. the findings are consistent with the global average prevalence of human alphacoronavirus, which ranges between 1% and 10%. the number of HCoV-229E infections detected in Malaysia was low, with no significant peak observed throughout the year. the study was performed in a relatively short duration, thus limiting the epidemiological and disease trend comparison with reports from other countries. a total of 42/45 (93.3%) partial S (S1 domain) and 43/45 (95.6%) of each complete N and partial 1a genes were successfully sequenced from HCoV-NL63 specimens. amplification of these genes was difficult for two xTAG-positive HCoV-NL63 specimens, possibly due to their low viral copy number. phylogenetic pattern was resulted from multiple recombination events along the HCoV-NL63 genome. the S1 region sequenced in this study is considered the most variable along the genome, while the N and 1a genes are too conserved. HCoV Genetic distance NL63 genotype A genotype B genotype C genotype A - 0.8 0.5 genotype B 7.6* - 0.6 genotype C 2.1 6.7 - 229E group 1 group 2 group 3 group 4 group 1 - 0.4 0.6 0.7 group 2 1.5 - 0.3 0.4 group 3 2.5 1.2 - 0.3 group 4 3.5 2.6 1.5 - * Pairwise genetic distances are expressed in percentage (%) of nucleotide difference HCoV-229E sequences (855 nucleotides) were color coded and the HCoV-229E groups 1–4 were indicated green = genotype 1, red = genotype 2, blue = genotype 3, and purple = genotype 4. the sampling site for each sequence was indicated by codes for the representation of countries. the divergence time of HCoV-229E was estimated around 1955. the tMRCA of group 1 diverged in 1976, followed by that of group 2 in 1981, group 3 in 1989, and group 4 in 1996. this is the first study that reported the divergence times of human alphacoronavirus genotypes. genetic characterization of human alphacoronavirus isolates currently circulating in Malaysia indicates the circulation of globally prevalent genotypes in the tropical region of southeast Asia.
